subtitle.Text: Steve: Around here you will find some of Sam's Super Nintendo cartridges that she left behind.
Obviously for legal reasons, we couldn't put real games in, and so we conscripted a few of our friends in the industry who are really talented artists to make
cool label art for fake Nintendo games that we came up with.
Karla: It's so true! The first one was Super Spitfire, and that was by Rachel Morris, who is a cool artist who, what is it, the NYU...?
Steve: The NYU Game Center, she's done a bunch of posters and other art for them.
Karla: And then the next one was Adventurous the Cat Returns, which is sort of a...
Steve: It's a mascot platformer, it's a Bubsy-esque 'tude-having cat...
Karla: Oh yeah. But it's a regular cat, it's not a bald cat. Steve: Yeah, it's a regular cat that rides a motorcycle towards an explosion. Karla: Yeah.
Steve: But yeah, Lee Petty is the art director at Double Fine, and worked on Brutal Legend, and I think he led up Stacking,
and yeah, he was nice enough to spend some of his free time making the label for Adventurous the Cat Returns.
Karla: Yeah, we ran into him at GDC and he offered to help us out, and we were all like, "Cool."
Steve: We were like, "Oh, you didn't think we'd take you up on that offer, did you? Draw us a cat!"
Karla: Yeah. He regretted the error of his ways. And then the third one is Journey of Crystal, which is sort of a JRPG... beast. And that was done by Jenn Zee...
Steve: Yeah, she's the Art Director at Supergiant, she did all of the art in Bastion, and is working on Transistor.
I know we had some people say that they could tell that it was her art because it has such a signature look...

Karla: It's pretty distinctive. Steve: ... to how she does things. So it was really cool and really exciting to have these really talented people from other studios that are inspirations to us contribute their unique art to the game.
